questions.text: A healthcare provider is assessing a postpartum mother with a viral infection for breastfeeding suitability. Given the mother's diagnosis, the provider must decide if breastfeeding should be contraindicated. Which viral infection in the mother commonly requires temporary cessation of breastfeeding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Herpes Simplex

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Hepatitis B is not a contraindication for breastfeeding as long as the infant receives the appropriate vaccinations.
  • • Option
  • • A: Hepatitis B
  • • not a contraindication for breastfeeding
  • • Option B: Hepatitis C is generally not considered a contraindication for breastfeeding . Transmission through breast milk is not common, and breastfeeding may continue unless there is nipple bleeding.
  • • Option
  • • B: Hepatitis C
  • • not considered a contraindication for breastfeeding
  • • Option D: Varicella Zoster, responsible for chickenpox , is not a contraindication for breastfeeding if the mother has immunity before pregnancy or if the baby has received varicella zoster immune globulin.
  • • Option
  • • D: Varicella Zoster,
  • • chickenpox

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While most maternal viral infections do not prohibit breastfeeding , certain conditions like active herpes simplex lesions on the breasts can necessitate temporary discontinuation of breastfeeding on the affected side to prevent the risk of neonatal transmission.
  • ➤ maternal viral infections
  • ➤ not prohibit breastfeeding
  • ➤ active herpes simplex lesions
  • ➤ breasts
  • ➤ temporary discontinuation of breastfeeding
  • ➤ affected side
  • ➤ prevent the risk of neonatal transmission.
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: A Medical Officer in a Regional healthcare center is addressing concerns of a mother who is worried about her milk supply being inadequate for her infant's needs. The MO assures her that breast milk composition typically provides all necessary nutrients in the right amounts. To demonstrate this point, she quizzes the interns present, about the sodium content of breast milk. What is the sodium content in breast milk measured in mEq/L?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 7 mEq/L

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Breast milk has a relatively low sodium content compared to other fluids , which is appropriate for the kidney's filtering capacity of an infant . On average, breast milk contains 7 mEq/L of sodium , which meets the infant's nutritional requirements without overloading their renal system.
  • • Breast milk
  • • relatively low sodium content
  • • other fluids
  • • appropriate for the kidney's filtering capacity
  • • infant
  • • breast milk contains 7 mEq/L of sodium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: A mother with a recent diagnosis of tuberculosis is being counselled. She is concerned about the risk of transmitting the infection to her newborn through breastfeeding. The Pediatrician advises her on when it would be safe to resume breastfeeding after starting antitubercular therapy. For how many weeks should breastfeeding be avoided after initiating antitubercular therapy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2 weeks

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Breastfeeding is generally contraindicated in mothers with tuberculosis until they have been on antitubercular therapy for a sufficient period to minimize the risk of transmitting the infection to the infant . The mother should avoid breastfeeding for the initial 2 weeks of treatment , as this is typically the period necessary for the mother to become non-infectious.
  • • Breastfeeding
  • • contraindicated in mothers with tuberculosis
  • • antitubercular therapy for a sufficient period
  • • minimize the risk of transmitting the infection to the infant
  • • mother should avoid breastfeeding
  • • initial 2 weeks of treatment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The recommendations for breastfeeding in the context of maternal tuberculosis and antitubercular therapy . Mothers can often resume breastfeeding safely after the infectious period has passed , which is generally after the first 2 weeks of therapy.
  • ➤ recommendations for breastfeeding
  • ➤ maternal tuberculosis
  • ➤ antitubercular therapy
  • ➤ Mothers
  • ➤ resume breastfeeding safely
  • ➤ infectious period has passed
  • ➤ after the first 2 weeks of therapy.
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: A 32-year-old working mother in a multinational company brings her 3-month-old infant to your clinic for a routine pediatric visit. After returning to work postpartum, she expresses a desire to transition her baby from breast milk to cow's milk due to her busy schedule. She inquires about the nutritional differences between human milk and cow's milk, specifically asking which component is present in higher quantities in human milk compared to cow's milk. Which of the following is the correct response?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lactose

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Calcium: Cow's milk actually contains higher levels of calcium than human milk . However, the bioavailability of calcium in human milk is better, meaning infants can absorb it more efficiently.
  • • Option B. Calcium:
  • • contains higher levels of calcium than human milk
  • • Option C. Protein: Cow's milk contains a higher concentration of total protein than human milk . The protein composition in cow's milk is also different, which can be harder for infants to digest and may lead to an increased risk of allergic reactions.
  • • Option C. Protein:
  • • higher concentration of total protein than human milk
  • • Option D. Fat: While the total fat content may be similar in both human and cow's milk , the composition of fat in human milk is uniquely suited to the human infant's needs, including essential fatty acids crucial for brain development that are not present in cow's milk in the same ratios.
  • • Option D. Fat:
  • • total fat content may be similar in both human
  • • cow's milk

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref : OP Ghai 9 th Page No- 145.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : OP Ghai 9 th Page No- 145.

questions.text: A 30-year-old first-time mother has just given birth to a healthy baby boy and is eager to begin breastfeeding. She consults you for advice on starting breastfeeding. Knowing that breastfeeding can typically commence immediately following a normal vaginal delivery, you review her medical history and note she has untreated tuberculosis, which is a known contraindication to breastfeeding. Concerned for the well-being of both mother and child, you plan to discuss alternative feeding options. Based on this scenario, which of the following are also considered contraindications to breastfeeding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Both A and B

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A: Galactosemia in the infant is a rare genetic metabolic disorder where the infant cannot properly metabolize galactose , a sugar present in milk . Breastfeeding is contraindicated in infants with galactosemia because it can lead to serious complications , including liver damage , sepsis , and intellectual disability .
  • • Option A: Galactosemia
  • • infant is a rare genetic metabolic disorder
  • • infant cannot properly metabolize galactose
  • • sugar present in milk
  • • Breastfeeding
  • • contraindicated
  • • infants with galactosemia
  • • lead to serious complications
  • • liver damage
  • • sepsis
  • • intellectual disability
  • • Option B: Active HSV lesions on the breast pose a risk of transmitting the virus to the infant during breastfeeding. If the lesions are present on the breast , direct breastfeeding is contraindicated to prevent neonatal herpes , a potentially severe infection in newborns. However, if the lesions are not on the breast, breastfeeding can continue with precautions, including covering the lesions and practicing meticulous hand hygiene.
  • • Option B: Active HSV
  • • breast pose a risk of transmitting the virus
  • • infant during breastfeeding.
  • • lesions
  • • present on the breast
  • • direct breastfeeding
  • • contraindicated to prevent neonatal herpes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Infant with Galactosemia and Active HSV of the breast are the contraindications of Breastfeeding.
  • ➤ Infant with Galactosemia
  • ➤ Active HSV of the breast
  • ➤ Breastfeeding.
  • ➤ Absolute contraindications to Breastfeeding are
  • ➤ contraindications to Breastfeeding are
  • ➤ HIV in the developed world Active HSV of the breast Mother on radiotherapy Galactosemia Chemotherapy drugs Infant galactosemia
  • ➤ HIV in the developed world
  • ➤ Active HSV of the breast
  • ➤ Mother on radiotherapy
  • ➤ Galactosemia
  • ➤ Chemotherapy drugs
  • ➤ Infant galactosemia
  • ➤ Relative contraindications
  • ➤ Relative contraindications
  • ➤ Active untreated TB Active drug use (Meth, Cocaine, Heroin THC controversial)
  • ➤ Active untreated TB
  • ➤ Active drug use (Meth, Cocaine, Heroin THC controversial)
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 3793-3794.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 3793-3794.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman has just given birth to her first child, a healthy baby boy, via uncomplicated vaginal delivery at a local hospital that is known for its adherence to the Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative (BFHI). She is eager to start breastfeeding and asks for guidance to ensure the best start for her newborn. As her pediatrician, you discuss the BFHI guidelines with her to support her breastfeeding journey. Which of the following pieces of advice would NOT be consistent with the Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative guidelines?

options.label: A
options.text: Mothers and infant to be together for 24 hours a day

options.label: B
options.text: Mother to initiate breast feeding within 3 hours of normal delivery

options.label: C
options.text: Giving newborn infants no food or drink other then breast milk

questions.correct_answer: B. Mother to initiate breast feeding within 3 hours of normal delivery
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mother to initiate breast feeding within 3 hours of normal delivery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Mothers and infants to be together 24 hours a day: This guideline is part of the BFHI and is critical for promoting bonding , facilitating breastfeeding on demand, and helping both the mother and infant to recognize each other's cues.
  • • Option A. Mothers and infants to be together 24 hours a day:
  • • part of the BFHI
  • • critical for promoting bonding
  • • Option C. Giving newborn infants no food or drink other than breast milk, unless medically indicated : This is a core principle of the BFHI . Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for the first six months of life to achieve optimal growth, development, and health.
  • • Option C. Giving newborn infants no food or drink other than breast milk,
  • • unless medically indicated
  • • core principle of the BFHI
  • • Option D. Encouraging breastfeeding on demand: This guideline aligns with the BFHI's emphasis on feeding infants whenever they show signs of hunger , which supports effective breastfeeding and ensures the infant's needs are met promptly.
  • • Option D. Encouraging breastfeeding on demand:
  • • guideline aligns with the BFHI's emphasis on feeding infants
  • • signs of hunger

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Baby- Friendly practices
  • ➤ Baby- Friendly practices
  • ➤ Have a written breastfeeding policy that is routinely communicated to all health care staff Train all health care staff in skills necessary to implement this policy Inform all pregnant women about the benefits and management of breastfeeding Help mothers initiate breastfeeding with 1 hour of birth Show mothers h ow to breastfeed and how to maintain lactation, even if they should be separated from their infants Give newborn infants no food or drink other than breast milk unless medically indicated Practice “rooming in” by allowing mothers and infants to remain together 24h/d Encourage breastfeeding on demand Give no artificial teats, pacifiers, dummies, or soothers to breastfeeding infants Foster the establishment of breastfeeding support groups and refer mothers to them on discharge from the hospital or clinic
  • ➤ Have a written breastfeeding policy that is routinely communicated to all health care staff
  • ➤ Train all health care staff in skills necessary to implement this policy
  • ➤ Inform all pregnant women about the benefits and management of breastfeeding
  • ➤ Help mothers initiate breastfeeding with 1 hour of birth
  • ➤ Show mothers h ow to breastfeed and how to maintain lactation, even if they should be separated from their infants
  • ➤ Give newborn infants no food or drink other than breast milk unless medically indicated
  • ➤ Practice “rooming in” by allowing mothers and infants to remain together 24h/d
  • ➤ Encourage breastfeeding on demand
  • ➤ Give no artificial teats, pacifiers, dummies, or soothers to breastfeeding infants
  • ➤ Foster the establishment of breastfeeding support groups and refer mothers to them on discharge from the hospital or clinic
  • ➤ EBF should be initiated as soon as possible (NVD it is 30 minutes)
  • ➤ EBF should be initiated as soon as possible (NVD it is 30 minutes)
  • ➤ Ref : Op Ghai 8 th Edition. Page No- From 97.
  • ➤ Ref : Op Ghai 8 th Edition. Page No- From 97.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to a well-baby clinic in a suburban area near Mumbai for a routine check-up. The mother is a first-time parent and is concerned about her baby's nutrition, as she has been exclusively breastfeeding. She reports that the baby is active, achieving developmental milestones appropriately, and has good urine output. However, she is worried if her breast milk alone is sufficient for the baby's nutritional needs, especially considering the energy and nutrient requirements for optimal growth. The pediatrician decides to educate her about the nutritional content of breast milk. Considering the average composition of breast milk, how much energy (in kcal) and what amounts of protein, fat, and carbohydrates (in grams) would you expect to find in 100 ml of breast milk?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 67 kcal, 1.1g protein, 4g fat, 7.4g carbohydrates

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Breast milk is known for its optimal mix of nutrients , vital for the growth and development of infants . On average, each 100 ml of breast milk provides about 67 kcal of energy . It contains approximately 1.1 grams of protein , which is essential for growth and development . The 4 grams of fat in breast milk are crucial for brain development and provide a significant portion of the energy. The 7.4 grams of carbohydrates , primarily lactose , not only supply energy but also aid in the absorption of calcium.
  • • Breast milk
  • • optimal mix of nutrients
  • • vital for the growth
  • • development of infants
  • • each 100 ml of breast milk provides about 67 kcal of energy
  • • approximately 1.1 grams of protein
  • • growth and development
  • • 4 grams of fat in breast milk
  • • brain development
  • • 7.4 grams of carbohydrates
  • • lactose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Breast milk provides a balanced mix of energy , protein, fat, and carbohydrates , making it the ideal food for infants.
  • ➤ Breast milk
  • ➤ balanced mix of energy
  • ➤ protein, fat, and carbohydrates
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 3789
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 3789

questions.text: A pediatrician demonstrates a feeding technique to a mother who is unable to breastfeed due to a recent surgery. Which feeding method is being demonstrated in the below image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Supplementary suckling technique

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Breastfeeding typically involves direct latching to the breast without the aid of devices; thus, it is not the correct answer.
  • • Option
  • • B: Breastfeeding
  • • involves direct latching to the breast
  • • Option D: Cup feeding is another alternative feeding method where a baby is fed using a small cup , which is not what is depicted in the image.
  • • Option
  • • D: Cup feeding
  • • alternative feeding method
  • • baby is fed using a small cup

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Supplementary suckling technique helps to maintain the breastfeeding bond and stimulates milk production while ensuring the baby receives adequate nutrition.
  • ➤ Supplementary suckling technique
  • ➤ maintain the breastfeeding bond
  • ➤ stimulates milk production
  • ➤ baby receives adequate nutrition.
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 3789
  • ➤ Ref :
  • ➤ Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 3789

questions.text: During a clinical session, a pediatrician discusses the nutritional aspects of various milk options. The discussion turns to the topic of Vitamin K, which is crucial for blood clotting and bone development. The students are presented with three different milk sources for infants and are asked to arrange them in descending order of Vitamin K content. Which of the following represents the correct sequence?

options.label: A
options.text: More in formula milk > cow milk > breast milk

options.label: B
options.text: More in cow's milk > breast milk > formula milk

options.label: C
options.text: More in cow's milk > buffalo milk > breast milk

options.label: D
options.text: More in cow's milk > formula milk > breast milk

questions.correct_answer: D. More in cow's milk > formula milk > breast milk
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) More in cow's milk > formula milk > breast milk

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cow's milk naturally contains higher levels of Vitamin K compared to human breast milk . While infant formula is fortified with various vitamins , the amount of Vitamin K is usually less than that found in cow's milk but more than that in human breast milk. The answer reflects the typical Vitamin K content hierarchy among the given milk sources.
  • • Cow's milk naturally contains higher levels of Vitamin K
  • • human breast milk
  • • infant formula is fortified
  • • various vitamins
  • • amount of Vitamin K
  • • less than that found in cow's milk

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Breast milk is deficient vitamin d , vitamin k and vitamin b 12 ( if mother is a pure vegetarian)
  • ➤ Breast milk
  • ➤ deficient vitamin d
  • ➤ vitamin k
  • ➤ vitamin b 12
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: In a discussion about the prevention of mother-to-child transmission of HIV, a pediatrician is advising a postpartum patient with HIV on feeding practices for her newborn. The pediatrician emphasizes the importance of one feeding method to reduce the risk of transmission. Which feeding method is contraindicated for infants born to HIV-positive mothers due to an increased risk of transmission?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mixed feeding

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended when replacement feeding (like formula) is not acceptable , feasible , affordable , sustainable , and safe (AFASS criteria). When these conditions are met, exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months, combined with antiretroviral therapy (ART) for the mother, can be a safe option.
  • • Option
  • • A: Exclusive breastfeeding
  • • replacement feeding
  • • not acceptable
  • • feasible
  • • affordable
  • • sustainable
  • • safe
  • • Option B: Replacement feeding with formula or animal milk may be recommended if it meets the AFASS criteria and if the mother has access to a regular supply of nutritionally adequate and safe formula, as well as the means to prepare it safely.
  • • Option
  • • B: Replacement feeding
  • • formula or animal milk
  • • recommended
  • • meets the AFASS criteria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key takeaway is that mixed feeding increases the risk of HIV transmission , while exclusive breastfeeding and replacement feeding have their indications based on specific criteria and availability of safe alternatives.
  • ➤ key takeaway
  • ➤ mixed feeding increases the risk of HIV transmission
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: A new mother asks about the differences in the composition of breast milk throughout a feeding session. She is curious about what the "hind milk," produced towards the end of the feeding, is known to be particularly rich in. What is the primary nutrient that hind milk is rich in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fat

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hind milk , which is the milk at the end of a breastfeeding session , is rich in fat . This higher fat content contributes to its satiety value , helping the infant feel full and satisfied after feeding , and it is essential for the baby's growth and energy .
  • • Hind milk
  • • milk at the end of a breastfeeding session
  • • rich in fat
  • • higher fat content
  • • satiety value
  • • infant feel full and satisfied after feeding
  • • baby's growth and energy
  • • Note - Amino acids are the building blocks of proteins, and while they are present in all milk, they are not specifically abundant in hind milk compared to the foremilk .
  • • Note - Amino acids are the building blocks of proteins, and while they are present in all milk, they are not specifically abundant in hind milk compared to the foremilk

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Foremilk , the initial milk expressed at the start of feeding , is typically higher in vitamins and protein . In contrast, hind milk is rich in fat and provides the calories needed for the infant to grow and feel satiated . This is crucial for advising breastfeeding mothers about the importance of allowing the baby to feed until they naturally release the breast, ensuring they receive both the foremilk and the hind milk.
  • ➤ Foremilk
  • ➤ initial milk expressed at the start of feeding
  • ➤ higher in vitamins and protein
  • ➤ hind milk is rich in fat
  • ➤ provides the calories needed for the infant to grow and feel satiated
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: In a clinic, a pediatrician discusses with new parents the complex composition of breast milk and its benefits beyond basic nutrition. She highlights a specific component that plays a crucial role in the development and healing of the infant's digestive system, especially important for premature babies or those with gastrointestinal issues. Which component in breast milk is specifically known for its role in aiding the repair of the infant's intestinal lining?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Epidermal Growth Factor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Secretory IgA is primarily involved in providing immunity to the infant , not in tissue repair.
  • • Option A: Secretory IgA
  • • providing immunity to the infant
  • • Option B: Lactoferrin has antibacterial properties and supports the infant's immune system rather than directly repairing tissues.
  • • Option B: Lactoferrin
  • • antibacterial properties
  • • supports the infant's immune system
  • • Option C: Cytokines are involved in immune responses and signalling , rather than the direct repair of the intestinal lining.
  • • Option C: Cytokines
  • • involved in immune responses
  • • signalling

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of EGF in breast milk is support the structural development and healing of the infant's intestinal tract , thereby enhancing overall gastrointestinal health.
  • ➤ presence of EGF in breast milk
  • ➤ support the structural development
  • ➤ healing of the infant's intestinal tract
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: A mother, anxious about her newborn's nutrition, consults a nurse about breastfeeding effectiveness. The nurse reassures her by explaining the natural changes in breast fullness associated with milk production and removal. She mentions a particular postpartum day by which the mother can expect her breasts to feel noticeably emptier after each feed, indicating a well-established feeding pattern and effective milk removal. What is this significant day postpartum?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Day 6

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A, Option B, Option C : These earlier days are part of the initial milk production phase , where the feeling of breast fullness might still be adjusting and does not necessarily indicate the efficiency of breastfeeding.
  • • Option A, Option B, Option C
  • • earlier days are part of the initial milk production phase
  • • feeling of breast fullness
  • • adjusting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The reduction in breast fullness after feeds by day 6 is a positive sign of effective breastfeeding , providing reassurance to new mothers about their breastfeeding journey.
  • ➤ reduction in breast fullness after feeds by day 6
  • ➤ positive sign of effective breastfeeding
  • ➤ reassurance to new mothers
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: A working mother concerned about maintaining her breast milk supply for her newborn consults a lactation expert. The expert emphasizes the importance of mimicking the baby's natural feeding frequency to maintain milk production, even when separated. She advises a minimum number of daily expressions to ensure lactation is sustained. What is the recommended minimum frequency of milk expression for a mother to maintain an adequate supply?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 8-10 times/day

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A, Option B, Option C : These frequencies might be insufficient for some mothers to maintain an optimal milk supply, potentially leading to a decrease in lactation over time.
  • • Option A, Option B, Option C
  • • frequencies might be insufficient

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The necessity of expressing milk 8-10 times a day for working mothers or those unable to breastfeed directly , ensuring the continuation of lactation and the availability of breast milk for the infant.
  • ➤ necessity of expressing milk 8-10 times a day for working mothers
  • ➤ unable to breastfeed directly
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: A pediatrician is counseling new parents on the nutritional needs of their newborn. While discussing the comprehensive benefits of breast milk, she points out a limitation regarding its Vitamin D content. She explains that breast milk has a certain range of Vitamin D per liter, which is not sufficient to meet the daily requirements of an infant, necessitating supplementation. What is the average Vitamin D content in breast milk?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 12-60 U

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Breast milk contains between 12-60 units of Vitamin D per liter , which is below the recommended daily intake for infants. Given this deficiency, supplemental Vitamin D is advised for breastfed infants to ensure they receive adequate amounts for healthy bone development.
  • • Breast milk contains between 12-60 units of Vitamin D per liter
  • • supplemental Vitamin D is advised for breastfed infants

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mother’s milk is deficient in vitamin D – it has 12-60 units of vitamin D .
  • ➤ Mother’s milk is deficient in vitamin D
  • ➤ 12-60 units of vitamin D
  • ➤ A term newborn baby is given around 400 international units & preterm 800-1000 IU of vitamin D till 1 year of life
  • ➤ term newborn baby is given around 400 international units
  • ➤ preterm 800-1000 IU of vitamin D
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: During a routine checkup, a neonatologist discusses Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) with the parents of a premature infant. The doctor emphasizes the benefits of KMC for both the infant and the parents but notes that there's an ideal weight at which KMC is generally initiated to ensure the infant's safety and well-being. What is the minimum weight recommended for starting KMC with a hemodynamically stable infant?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1.8 kg

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Kangaroo Mother Care is typically recommended for infants weighing at least 1.8 kg who are also hemodynamically stable , as this weight suggests a level of physiological stability conducive to the practice .
  • • Kangaroo Mother Care
  • • infants weighing at least 1.8 kg
  • • hemodynamically stable
  • • level of physiological stability conducive to the practice

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kangaroo Mother Care , a method beneficial for the development and bonding of infants , especially preterm ones , is typically initiated when an infant reaches a certain weight threshold , ensuring the practice's safety and effectiveness.
  • ➤ Kangaroo Mother Care
  • ➤ development and bonding of infants
  • ➤ preterm ones
  • ➤ initiated when an infant reaches a certain weight threshold
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: In a discussion on infant care practices, a pediatrician highlights the importance of post-feeding positioning to reduce the risk of a particular syndrome. She advises against placing the infant in a prone position immediately after feeding to minimize this risk. What condition is primarily being prevented by this recommendation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The recommendation to avoid the prone position immediately after feeding is primarily aimed at reducing the risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS), as this position can compromise an infant's airway and breathing post-feeding .
  • • prone position immediately after feeding
  • • aimed at reducing the risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome
  • • compromise an infant's airway
  • • breathing post-feeding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The aim is to reinforce safe infant care practices , particularly the avoidance of the prone position immediately after feeding , to lower the risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS), thereby promoting safer sleep and care environments for infants.
  • ➤ aim is to reinforce safe infant care practices
  • ➤ avoidance of the prone position
  • ➤ after feeding
  • ➤ lower the risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: In a breastfeeding support group session, a nurse explains the physiological mechanisms facilitating successful breastfeeding. She elaborates on a crucial reflex that enables milk flow from the glands to the nipple, essential for effective feeding. This reflex is triggered by the infant's suckling and is known by a more common term in lactation discussions. What is the widely recognized name for the draught reflex, crucial for the breastfeeding process?

options.label: A
options.text: Milk Ejection Reflex / Let Down Reflex

questions.correct_answer: A. Milk Ejection Reflex / Let Down Reflex
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Milk Ejection Reflex / Let Down Reflex

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The draught reflex , integral to successful breastfeeding , is more commonly referred to as the Milk Ejection Reflex or the Let Down Reflex . This reflex is crucial for moving milk from the mammary glands to the ducts and then to the nipple , facilitating breastfeeding.
  • • draught reflex
  • • integral to successful breastfeeding
  • • Milk Ejection Reflex or the Let Down Reflex
  • • moving milk from the mammary glands
  • • ducts
  • • then to the nipple

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Milk Ejection Reflex (also known as the Draught Reflex or Let Down Reflex) is a key physiological process in breastfeeding , enabling the transfer of milk from the mother to the infant and ensuring effective lactation.
  • ➤ Milk Ejection Reflex
  • ➤ physiological process in breastfeeding
  • ➤ transfer of milk from the mother to the infant
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: During a routine pediatric visit, a doctor assesses a mother and her newborn to ensure effective breastfeeding. She observes the breastfeeding technique, focusing on the baby's latch and attachment, which are pivotal for successful feeding. The doctor looks for specific signs indicating a good latch, contributing to an efficient and comfortable breastfeeding experience for both the mother and the infant. Which of the following represents the correct combination of signs indicative of good attachment? Chin touching the breast Mouth wide open with fullness of cheeks Lower lip everted out Upper areola exposed out
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Options 1, 2, 3, and 4 are right

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Good attachment is characterized by the infant's chin touching the breast , a wide-open mouth with full cheeks , the lower lip everted outwards , and more of the upper areola being visible , ensuring efficient milk transfer and a comfortable breastfeeding experience .
  • • Good attachment
  • • infant's chin touching the breast
  • • wide-open mouth with full cheeks
  • • lower lip everted outwards
  • • more of the upper areola being visible
  • • efficient milk transfer
  • • comfortable breastfeeding experience

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The critical signs of good attachment during breastfeeding , including the infant's chin , mouth , cheeks , lips , and areola positioning , which are essential for effective milk transfer and a positive breastfeeding experience.
  • ➤ critical signs of good attachment
  • ➤ breastfeeding
  • ➤ infant's chin
  • ➤ mouth
  • ➤ cheeks
  • ➤ lips
  • ➤ areola positioning
  • ➤ effective milk transfer
  • ➤ positive breastfeeding experience.
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: A common misconception is addressed regarding which hormone is responsible for milk production versus milk ejection. Is it true or false that prolactin oozes out the milk, and oxytocin produces the milk?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) False

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The statement is false . Prolactin is the hormone responsible for stimulating milk production within the mammary glands . In contrast, oxytocin triggers the milk ejection reflex , enabling the milk to be released from the nipple .
  • • false
  • • Prolactin
  • • hormone
  • • stimulating milk production within the mammary glands
  • • oxytocin triggers the milk ejection reflex
  • • milk to be released from the nipple

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Remember P = P
  • ➤ P = P
  • ➤ PROLACTIN PRODUCES THE MILK
  • ➤ PROLACTIN PRODUCES THE MILK
  • ➤ O=O
  • ➤ OXYTOCIN OOZES OUT THE MILK
  • ➤ OXYTOCIN OOZES OUT THE MILK
  • ➤ Role of Prolactin and Oxytocin in lactation: prolactin for milk production and oxytocin for the milk ejection reflex.
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: In a discussion on the nutritional composition of breast milk, a lactation expert emphasizes the importance of understanding the key nutrients that contribute to infant growth and development. She points out that breast milk contains a predominant carbohydrate that not only serves as a crucial energy source for infants but also aids in the absorption of calcium and other minerals. What is the primary carbohydrate found in breast milk, known for its sweet taste and nutritional benefits?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lactose

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Lactose is the predominant carbohydrate in breast milk , contributing to its sweet taste . It plays a vital role in providing energy to the infant and facilitating the absorption of essential minerals , such as calcium.
  • • Lactose
  • • predominant carbohydrate in breast milk
  • • sweet taste
  • • providing energy to the infant
  • • facilitating the absorption of essential minerals
  • • Explanation:
  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Galactocerebrosidase is an enzyme , not a carbohydrate.
  • • Option B: Galactocerebrosidase
  • • enzyme
  • • Option C: Minerals are a component of breast milk but not carbohydrates.
  • • Option C: Minerals
  • • component of breast milk
  • • Option D: Combining lactose and galactocerebrosidase does not make sense in this context, as the question asks for the predominant carbohydrate.
  • • Option D: Combining lactose and galactocerebrosidase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lactose is the primary carbohydrate in breast milk , providing energy and supporting the absorption of minerals , highlighting the nutritional completeness of breast milk for infant growth and development.
  • ➤ Lactose
  • ➤ primary carbohydrate in breast milk
  • ➤ energy and supporting the absorption of minerals
  • ➤ nutritional completeness of breast milk
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: During a nutrition-based seminar, a speaker discusses the critical components of breast milk that support the neurological development of infants. One particular fatty acid in breast milk is highlighted for its significant role in the growth and development of the central nervous system and visual acuity. Which fatty acid is recognized for its crucial contribution to brain and eye development in infants?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Docosahexaenoic Acid (DHA)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: TGF Beta is involved in immune regulation, not directly related to CNS or eye development.
  • • Option A: TGF Beta is involved in immune regulation,
  • • CNS or eye development.
  • • Option B: Para Amino Benzoic Acid is not a fatty acid linked to CNS or eye development in the context of breast milk.
  • • Option B: Para Amino Benzoic Acid
  • • fatty acid linked to CNS or eye development
  • • Option D: None of the Above is incorrect as DHA is indeed present in breast milk and crucial for CNS and eye development.
  • • Option D: None of the Above
  • • incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Docosahexaenoic Acid (DHA) is a key component in breast milk essential for the development of the infant's brain and eyes, underscoring the importance of breast milk in supporting early neurological and visual development.
  • ➤ Docosahexaenoic Acid
  • ➤ breast milk
  • ➤ development of the infant's brain
  • ➤ eyes,
  • ➤ importance of breast milk
  • ➤ early neurological and visual development.
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: In a pediatric care unit, a nurse educates a concerned mother whose newborn is experiencing jaundice. She explains that a certain component in breast milk can contribute to this condition, known as breast milk jaundice, which typically appears in the first week of life and can persist longer than typical newborn jaundice. This component affects bilirubin metabolism and promotes enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin. What is this component associated with breast milk jaundice?

options.label: A
options.text: 3 Alpha 20 Beta Diol & Beta Glucuronidase enzyme

questions.correct_answer: A. 3 Alpha 20 Beta Diol & Beta Glucuronidase enzyme
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 3 Alpha 20 Beta Diol & Beta Glucuronidase enzyme

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Galactokinase is involved in carbohydrate metabolism , not directly related to bilirubin metabolism and jaundice.
  • • Option B: Galactokinase
  • • carbohydrate metabolism
  • • Option C: This option is incorrect as there are known components in breast milk that can contribute to jaundice.
  • • Option
  • • C: This option
  • • components in breast milk
  • • contribute to jaundice.
  • • Option D: 20 Beta Prednione is not a recognized component in breast milk affecting bilirubin metabolism.
  • • Option
  • • D: 20 Beta Prednione

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Certain components in breast milk , specifically 3 Alpha 20 Beta Diol and Beta Glucuronidase , can contribute to the development of breast milk jaundice by affecting bilirubin metabolism and promoting its enterohepatic circulation , leading to a prolonged jaundice period in affected infants .
  • ➤ breast milk
  • ➤ 3 Alpha 20 Beta Diol
  • ➤ Beta Glucuronidase
  • ➤ development of breast milk jaundice
  • ➤ affecting bilirubin metabolism
  • ➤ promoting its enterohepatic circulation
  • ➤ prolonged jaundice period
  • ➤ affected infants
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1799
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1799

questions.text: For each pathogen listed in Column A, select the protective component from Column B that breast milk provides to help guard the infant against that particular pathogen. Match the pathogen with the correct breast milk component:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A-4, B-3, C-1, D-2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Bifidus Factor is known to help protect infants from intestinal pathogens such as Shigella . Lysozyme has antibacterial properties effective against E. histolytica . Lactoferrin , with its iron-binding capability , inhibits the growth of G. lamblia. Para Amino Benzoic Acid (PABA) is believed to provide protection against malaria.
  • • The Bifidus Factor is known to help protect infants from intestinal pathogens such as Shigella .
  • • Bifidus Factor
  • • help protect infants
  • • intestinal pathogens such as Shigella
  • • Lysozyme has antibacterial properties effective against E. histolytica .
  • • Lysozyme
  • • antibacterial properties effective against E. histolytica
  • • Lactoferrin , with its iron-binding capability , inhibits the growth of G. lamblia.
  • • Lactoferrin
  • • iron-binding capability
  • • Para Amino Benzoic Acid (PABA) is believed to provide protection against malaria.
  • • Para Amino Benzoic Acid
  • • protection against malaria.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: A dietitian calculates the daily caloric needs of infants based on their weight using the Holiday-Segar Formula. A mother presents with her 7 kg baby, and the dietitian sets out to determine the infant's daily kilocalorie requirement. Using the standard caloric requirements per kilogram of body weight for infants, how many kilocalories per day does this 7 kg baby require?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 700 kcal

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • According to the Holiday-Segar Formula , infants weighing 1-10 kg require 100 kcal/kg/day . Therefore, a 7 kg baby would require 700 kcal/day (7 kg x 100 kcal/kg/day).
  • • Holiday-Segar Formula
  • • infants weighing 1-10 kg
  • • 100 kcal/kg/day
  • • 7 kg baby would require 700 kcal/day

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Holiday-Segar Formula – The kilocalories requirement is
  • ➤ Holiday-Segar Formula
  • ➤ kilocalories requirement
  • ➤ 1-10 kg babies –100 kcal per kg
  • ➤ 10-20 kg - 50 kcal / kg
  • ➤ >20 kg - 20 kcal/ kg
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1780
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1780

questions.text: A pediatrician is reviewing metabolic disorders and their clinical presentations with medical residents. The topic of galactosemia and its associated symptoms arises. Based on the latest updates in medical knowledge, the pediatrician poses a question about the correlation between galactosemia and macrocephaly. Does galactosemia cause macrocephaly?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) True

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Galactosemia is a metabolic disorder that can lead to macrocephaly , among other symptoms. This is due to the accumulation of galactose in the blood , which can affect multiple organ systems , including the brain.
  • • Galactosemia
  • • metabolic disorder
  • • lead to macrocephaly
  • • accumulation of galactose in the blood
  • • affect multiple organ systems
  • • brain.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The absolute contraindication of breast feeding is galactosemia and it can cause macrocephaly in the baby
  • ➤ absolute contraindication of breast feeding
  • ➤ galactosemia
  • ➤ cause macrocephaly in the baby
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: In a Neonatal intensive care unit, a neonatologist assesses a newborn delivered at 27 weeks of gestation to determine the appropriate method of nutritional support. Given the infant's premature status, the neonatologist must choose the safest and most effective route of feeding. Which method of nutrition is most appropriate for a newborn at this stage of gestational development?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) IV Fluids

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Breastfeeding is typically not possible for infants born at 27 weeks due to underdeveloped suck-swallow coordination and the high risk of aspiration.
  • • Option
  • • A: Breastfeeding
  • • not possible for infants born at 27 weeks
  • • underdeveloped suck-swallow coordination
  • • Option B & C: Paladai Feed and Katori Spoon Feed are methods used for slightly older preterm infants who have more mature gastrointestinal systems.
  • • Option
  • • B & C: Paladai Feed and Katori Spoon
  • • methods used for slightly older preterm infants

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ < 28 weeks: Intravenous fluids
  • ➤ 28-32 weeks: nasogastric / orogastric feeding
  • ➤ 32-34 weeks: paladai feed
  • ➤ >34 weeks: breast feeding
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: During a session on infant feeding in areas with high rates of HIV, a public health specialist outlines the conditions that must be met for replacement feeding to be considered a suitable alternative to breastfeeding. These criteria are designed to ensure the safety and health of the infant where breastfeeding is contraindicated. What does AFASS stand for in the context of replacement feeding?

options.label: C
options.text: Partially Acceptable, Affordable, Feasible, Sustainable & Safe

questions.correct_answer: D. Acceptable, Affordable, Feasible, Sustainable & Safe
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Acceptable, Affordable, Feasible, Sustainable & Safe

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Replacement feeding options should be Acceptable to the caregiver and family , Affordable within the family's budget , Feasible to implement consistently and correctly, Sustainable over time , and Safe from contaminants and pathogens .
  • • Replacement feeding
  • • Acceptable to the caregiver and family
  • • Affordable within the family's budget
  • • Feasible to implement consistently
  • • Sustainable over time
  • • Safe from contaminants and pathogens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To comprehend the AFASS criteria for replacement feeding , which ensure that non-breastfeeding options are safe and practical for infants who cannot be breastfed , particularly in contexts where HIV transmission risk must be minimized.
  • ➤ comprehend the AFASS criteria
  • ➤ replacement feeding
  • ➤ ensure that non-breastfeeding options are safe
  • ➤ practical for infants
  • ➤ cannot be breastfed
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: A breastfeeding mother inquiries about nighttime feeds and their impact on milk production. The lactation consultant explains that a certain hormone, which plays a pivotal role in milk synthesis, is secreted in higher amounts during the night. Which hormone increases in secretion during the night, making nighttime breastfeeding beneficial for milk supply?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Prolactin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Prolactin , known as the milk-producing hormone , has higher levels of secretion during the night . This is why nighttime breastfeeding is often recommended to help maintain a robust milk supply .
  • • Prolactin
  • • milk-producing hormone
  • • higher levels of secretion during the night
  • • nighttime breastfeeding
  • • help maintain a robust milk supply

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The significance of prolactin in lactation , especially its increased nocturnal secretion , which supports the rationale for encouraging nighttime breastfeeding to enhance and maintain milk production .
  • ➤ prolactin in lactation
  • ➤ increased nocturnal secretion
  • ➤ rationale for encouraging nighttime breastfeeding
  • ➤ enhance and maintain milk production
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1799
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1799

questions.text: A pediatrician is discussing weaning with a group of parents. She introduces the concept of 'token breastfeeding’. Which of the following best describes token breastfeeding?

options.label: A
options.text: If an infant mostly has breastfed and less outside food, it is called as token breastfeeding.

options.label: B
options.text: If an infant mostly has other food with no breastfeeds, it is called as token breastfeeding.

options.label: C
options.text: If an infant mostly has other food, but still breastfeeds occasionally, it is called as token breastfeeding.

questions.correct_answer: C. If an infant mostly has other food, but still breastfeeds occasionally, it is called as token breastfeeding.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) If an infant mostly has other food, but still breastfeeds occasionally, it is called as token breastfeeding.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Token breastfeeding occurs when an infant primarily consumes foods other than breast milk but still engages in occasional breastfeeding sessions.
  • • Token breastfeeding
  • • infant primarily consumes foods
  • • breast milk

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Token breastfeeding is the practice where infants primarily eat complementary foods but continue to breastfeed on a non-nutritive basis , typically as a means of comfort or routine .
  • ➤ Token breastfeeding
  • ➤ infants primarily eat complementary foods
  • ➤ continue to breastfeed on a non-nutritive basis
  • ➤ means of comfort or routine
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1795
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1795

questions.text: An intern is reviewing contraindications for breastfeeding. He must identify scenarios where breastfeeding would not be advisable for the infant's safety. Which of the following conditions is considered a contraindication to breastfeeding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Mothers undergoing chemotherapy or radiotherapy may excrete toxic substances in breast milk that could harm the infant.
  • • Option
  • • A: Mothers undergoing chemotherapy or radiotherapy
  • • excrete toxic substances in breast milk
  • • Option B: Infants with galactosemia cannot metabolize the galactose in breast milk , leading to serious complications.
  • • Option
  • • B: Infants with galactosemia
  • • cannot metabolize the galactose in breast milk
  • • Option C: While true lactose intolerance in infants is rare, if present, it would necessitate an alternative to lactose-containing breast milk.
  • • Option
  • • C: While true lactose intolerance in infants is rare,

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The contraindications to breastfeeding , includes maternal treatments such as chemotherapy or radiotherapy and certain metabolic conditions in the infant , such as galactosemia .
  • ➤ contraindications
  • ➤ breastfeeding
  • ➤ maternal treatments such as chemotherapy
  • ➤ radiotherapy
  • ➤ certain metabolic conditions
  • ➤ infant
  • ➤ galactosemia
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1797
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1797
